title: Four Directions 5k opens race relations conversation
content: RAPID CITY, S.D. (KOTA TV) - Rapid City Community Conversations, a native-led grassroots movement, is on a mission to tackle racism in the community.    They do this though creating dialogue and on Saturday morning they continued that conversation through their third annual Four Directions 5k.    "It's not easy. There are trust issues but we need to work together to improve racism in Rapid City and we are working really really hard on that issue," said Beverly Running Bear, a council elder for RCCC.    This 5K is a celebration of their work throughout the year and is meant to create a meaningful and positive way of addressing these tough issues.    "It doesn't work too well to have protests and negativity so it's better to sit down with focus groups and listen to each other," said Dolores Stabber, a council elder for RCCC.    The council elders are made up of people from all different background and ethnicities and they encourage others to get involved.    "Lets try and transform the mentality of the people around us. Let's heal the historical trauma we have," said Bobbi Jean Jarvinen. "Maybe not heal it, but understand it so it gives a place for people who have suffered historical trauma to come and someone like me to go and listen to their stories."     "Regardless of race, ethnicity or language we are one. It is just all of us being one," said Dr. Sandra Ogunremi, council elder for RCCC.
